title: 107_hr655
content:
The "Commission to Study the Culture of Violence in America Act" establishes a commission to study the culture of violence in America and outlines the duties of the Commission. The Commission established by the "Commission to Study the Culture of Violence in America Act" is tasked with examining the glorification of violence, the relationship between psychological stress and increased violence, the role of the media in promoting violence, the correlation between access to firearms and violence, the role of schools in identifying potential perpetrators of violence, and making recommendations to address these issues. The Commission, composed of 22 members appointed by various leaders, must have special knowledge or experience in violence issues, including sociologists, psychologists, clergy, law enforcement officials, victims of violence, and media representatives. The Commission, composed of 22 members with expertise in violence issues, must not consider political affiliation in appointments. Members serve for the Commission's duration, vacancies filled as per original appointment method. Members do not receive pay but get travel expenses as per regulations. Nine members form a quorum for Commission business. The Commission, consisting of 22 members with expertise in violence issues, appoints a Chairperson to hold hearings and conduct meetings as needed. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson appoints Commission personnel and determines their pay. Staff appointments follow civil service laws. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission upon request.

SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and receive testimony to carry out its duties. It can delegate powers to members or agencies, obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission has the authority to contract with Government or private agencies for supplies or services, without following certain statutes. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within one year of all members being appointed, detailing their findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report.
